ASSOC_ACTOR_1: CHRF: Civil Human Rights Front; PP: People Power
SOURCE: Wen Wei Po; South China Morning Post
NOTES: On 1 January 2018, CHRF organized a march from Wan Chai to the East Wing Forecourt of the government headquarters in Admiralty, Central and Western District (Hong Kong) in opposition to last week's formal endorsement by the government of a ''co-location'' plan to set up a joint checkpoint at the West Kowloon station, which demonstrators felt would reduce Hong Kong's from Beijing. Towards the end of the demonstration, demonstrators from several groups, including People Power, broke into the East Wing Forecourt and attempted to rush onto the flag platform. They clashed with security personnel of the Government Headquarters, resulting in the injury of two demonstrators and one security personnel. Organisers said 10000 people participated but police put the turnout at 6200. [size=6200 to 10000]

On 11 January 2018, close to 10,000 residents gathered at a wetland park then marched on the streets of Renshou county (Meishan, Sichuan) to demonstrate against a recent government decision to re-zone six of its most developed villages and townships into its own county, effectively ''lowering'' Renshou county's development status. There were clashes between the demonstrators and 500 police officers deployed to the scene. Demonstrators took banners to a government building afterwards, and blocked several main arteries in the county. [size=close to 10,000]

On 12 January 2018, more than a dozen villagers clashed with 200-300 police officers at the construction site of a garbage incineration plant in Wangshan village, Qinghu town of Luchuan county (Yulin, Guangxi) in an attempt to stop the construction of the plant. Many people were injured and arrested as the police beat up elderly and female villagers with sticks, and the villagers threw rocks and bricks in retaliation. A few policemen and a dozen villagers were injured, and the villagers that were hospitalised were unconscious. Fourteen villagers were taken into police custody. [size=more than a dozen]

On 18 January 2018, more than 50 demonstrators petitioned in a local subdistrict governmental office of Pudong, in Shanghai. They lost their farmland to the local government. Physical scuffles broke out between the demonstrators and a group of security guards, as demonstrators attempted to push past the security guards who were blocking the entrance. [size=more than 50]

On 24 January 2018, clashes broke out between three thousand villagers and the police in Ange village, Wenping town, Ludian district (Zhaotong City, Yunnan) right after a heated argument between a 70-year-old woman and the sub-district secretary over the low compensation rate of a city reconstruction plan. The woman was reportedly pushed to the ground by the secretary and died at the scene, while her daughter-in-law was beaten. During the clash, the villagers threw stones to the police, injured several officers, and destroyed a number of police vehicles, and riot police from Zhaotong City was deployed later. According to some villagers, one police officers died during the riot and up to 100 officers were injured. [size=3000]

On 2 February 2018, as many as 100 workers demonstrated in Xuanwu (Nanjing, JIangsu) in response to unpaid wages. Demonstrators hit a police officer during a confrontation with police, after which police and SWAT police took away a few demonstrators. Demonstrators held banners. [size=as many as 100]

Around 12 February 2018, an unknown number of teachers demonstrated at the government office in Guanling Buyei and Miao Autonomous County (Anshun, Guizhou) against unfair bonus payment. A teacher was arrested after clashing with the police. This is part of a teachers-led massive demonstration spanning two days in Anshan, where up to 10,000 teachers participated in the demonstration in total. [size=no report]

On 28 March 2018, several dozen people were injured during a clash with Liuzhou authorities during the forced eviction in Caiyuantun in Liunan (Liuzhou, Guangxi). Around 60 villagers used wooden boxes and cupboards to set up two road blocks, threw bricks at law enforcement officials, and attacked with wooden sticks, metal shovels and sledgehammers. The police used truncheons and shields to attack the rioters resisting the eviction, and four people were also detained. Among those injured, 17 of them were law enforcement officials, 4 of which were hospitalised; there were at least 4 rioters who sustained scratches, and 1 had reportedly been hospitalised for a broken leg. Online rumours said that one person died, but this has yet to be verified. [size=several dozens]

On 2 April 2018, dozens of urban management personnel were dispatched by the local government to demolish houses in Libukou Township, Zhoukou City, Henan Province. Violent clashes broke out between the personnel and the more than 100 villagers who were resisting the demolishment. Several villagers sustained serious injuries after being beaten with shovels and rods. [size=more than 100]

ACTOR2: Police Forces of China (2012-) People's Armed Police
NOTES: On 3 April 2018, hundreds of villagers in Hedongcun, Xinyi (Maoming, Guangdong) continued clashing with police when they gathered at a construction site in their village to demonstrate against the authorities' plans to build a local waste incineration power plant. Armed police fired at least one tear gas grenade and sprayed pepper water on the villagers. The demonstrations had lasted for around a week as reported on 5 April. Police arrested dozens and injured at least 10 villagers between 2-4 April, resulting in two hospitalisations. [size=hundreds]

ACTOR2: Police Forces of China (2012-) People's Armed Police
NOTES: On 4 April 2018, hundreds of villagers in Hedongcun, Xinyi (Maoming, Guangdong) continued clashing with police when they gathered at a construction site in their village to demonstrate against the authorities' plans to build a local waste incineration power plant. Armed police beat villagers with batons and sprayed pepper water on the villagers. The demonstrations had lasted for around a week as reported on 5 April. Police arrested dozens and injured at least 10 villagers between 2-4 April, resulting in two hospitalisations. [size=hundreds]

On 4 April 2018, between 50 to nearly 100 triad members led by the town mayor and secretary arrived at Beiganjing Village (Xianyang, Shaanxi) and destroyed the crops to take over the land for construction. At least dozens of villagers tried to stop them and the two groups clashed with shovels. Several people got injured and one villager died after being sent to the hospital. [size=at least dozens]

On 6 April 2018, thousands of villagers from two villages in Changqi Town (Wuchuan, Zhanjiang, Guangdong) fought in two groups with each other while performing a traditional ''march with God'' new year ceremony. They fought during the day with iron sticks and at night by shooting fireworks as weapons. The authority sent hundreds of police to stop the situation. 4 villagers were injured. [size=thousands]

On 8 April 2018, a clash between police and more than 100 urban management personnel broke out in Suiyang District, Shangqiu (Henan province). Eight policemen were injured and four were taken to a hospital. The incident happened as the urban management personnel were trying to evict people from a residential area slated for redevelopment. [size=more than 100]

On 12 April 2018, more than 60 clients of the Agricultural Bank of China gathered outside the gate of the Agricultural Bank of China branch in Chenggaozi Town, Xiangfang District, Harbin, in opposition to the bank's failure to deliver a ''high-interest guarantee'' these clients purchased five years ago. Demonstrators clashed with the police, and three people were charged with ''attacking the police'' and detained for seven days. [size=60]

On 12 April 2018, a group of homeowners demonstrated outside a real estate residence in Huidong County, Guangdong, against the fact that that their estate was listed as an illegal building and was therefore assigned to be demolished immediately. Clashes between demonstrators and police broke out, and nine demonstrators were taken by the police. [size=no report]

On 13 April 2018, over 100 construction workers blocked a provincial road in Huizhou, Guangdong with scaffolding to demonstrate against wage arrears owed by a construction company. Traffic was stopped for an hour. Government intervened and the workers got paid by 18 April 2018. [size=over 100]

Around 18 April 2018 (as reported), up to 100 taxi drivers went on strike and intercepted Didi ride-sharing drivers around Jiexiu, Shanxi to retaliate against the competition they were facing from Didi drivers. A lot of people were not able to hail Didi drivers as a result of this. During the incident, a female Didi driver picked up 2 people who were pretending to be passengers, and they snatched away her car keys just as a group of taxi drivers surrounded her car and started to hit it. They prevented her from leaving and threatened her. People were reported to have been arrested at the Jiexiu Railway Station. [size=up to 100]

ACTOR2: Police Forces of China (2012-) People's Armed Police
SOURCE: CRLW; Radio Free Asia; Apple Daily Hong Kong
NOTES: On 2 May 2018, more than 300 Gaoling Township residents clashed with police at the Gaoling Township Government, Susong County, Anhui, while objecting the government's plans to build a local waste incineration plant. Rioters blocked the road and seized Gaoling Township Government, while people threw bricks and debris at the government building. Authorities dispatched heavily armed riot police officers to disperse people. At least 8 people were injured, including 1 government worker, 6 police and 1 elderly demonstrator. It was also suspected that 1 person died, but the authorities denied this. [size=more than 300]

On 11 May 2018, hundreds of teachers staged a demonstration and clashed with security guards in Zhangqiu City, Jinan, Shandong when demanding to be considered eligible for government service payment. [size=hundreds]

On 19 May 2018, around 60 villagers dumped 10 trucks of dirt in front of a Three-Self church in Xiangning county (Linfen, Shanxi), put up banners to demand that the church moved out, and got into scuffles with believers. Two believers were injured. The local government had instigated the villager in the hopes that they would force believers to shut down the church. [size=around 60]

ACTOR2: Police Forces of China (2012-) People's Armed Police
NOTES: On 21 May 2018, more than 100 villagers attempted to block the demolition of a newly-built nursing home in Xinzhan Town, Huaiyang District (Zhoukou City, Henan Province), where more than 100 special police officers and security guards were dispatched by the local government. It was reported that the villagers started verbally abusing the law enforcement personnel, and threw bricks, umbrellas and buckets towards the officers. During the altercation, some villagers were beaten by the law enforcement personnel. It was reported that the demolition was ordered by the local government, despite the construction having been approved by the government in February last year. [size=more than 100]

ACTOR2: Police Forces of China (2012-) People's Armed Police
NOTES: On 23 May 2018, hundreds of residents gathered at a mining site in Mapeng Village (Yulin City, Guangxi Province), holding banners and chanting slogans in opposition to the potential environmental and health issues caused by the mining operations. It was reported that the local village committee had approved the mining operation without consultation with the villagers. The special and anti-riot police were at the scene during the demonstration and clashed with the villagers. The police reportedly used their shields and batons to beat up villagers, causing some of the villagers to bleed in their heads. 16 villagers were arrested. [size=hundreds]

SOURCE: Apple Daily Hong Kong; Epoch Times; Radio Free Asia
NOTES: On 28 May 2018, between 200 and 500 fishermen gathered in front of Dongshan Town Government (Suzhou , Jiangsu) to oppose the prohibition of breeding hairy crabs in Lake Tai. They clashed with police. It was reported that 3 special police beat up one demonstrator, while several others were injured. The fishermen became discontented after hearing that an agreement between the government and some fishermen had been made. [size=between 200 and 500]

On 10 June 2018, bank customers gathered at an agricultural bank in Heilongjiang Province demanding to retrieve their bank savings. The demonstrators clashed with bank security guards and some people were injured. It was reported that the bank customers have not been able to retrieve their bank savings since 2013. [size=no report]

On 11 June 2018, more than 1000 rioters clashed with the police in front of the Changsha People's Government in Yuelu District (Changsha City, Hunan Province). The rioters were demonstrating against wage arrears owed to them by their employees. Many rioters were arrested. [size=more than 1000]

On 13 June 2018, descendants of the Tan family got into fights with demolition crew led by the head of the Hehua Subdistrict Office at the Tan Sitong Ancestral Hall in Liuyang City (Changsha City, Hunan Province) while trying to protect the Ancestral Hall from being demolished. Fully-geared police ended the commotion by surrounding the descendants. The ancestral hall was demolished within a few hours. [size=no reports]

On 13 June 2018, thousands of villagers clashed with the police in Hushan township (Quanzhou City, Fujian Province) during a demonstration against the construction plan of a waste incineration power plant. The police used tear gas to disperse the rioters. a large number of rioters were injured with blood on faces. The police arrested dozens of rioters. It was reported that the villagers had demonstrated for more than 10 days by blocking the entrance of the construction site. [size=thousands]

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: DHKC: Defend Hong Kong Campaign; Civilians (China); Government of China (2017-) Hong Kong Special Administrative Region
SOURCE: HK01; AFP; Channel News Asia; HKFP
NOTES: On 14 June 2018, during the legislative debate of the joint immigration arrangement bill, around 150 to 200 pan-democratic supporters and students who opposed the bill clashed with around 20 to 30 members of DHKC, a pro-Beijing group, outside the Legislative Council in the Central and Western District (Hong Kong). The two groups shouted at and pushed against each other. Council staff intervened and separated them. It was reported that the pan-democratic demonstrators opposed Chinese officials to conduct immigration checks at the joint checkpoint of a new rail terminus and enforce Chinese law including criminal law within parts of the station and on trains. They watched a live broadcast of the debate and the vote that followed. [size=between around 170 and 230]

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Former Military Forces of China (2012-); Women (China)
NOTES: On 21 June 2018, around 1000 retired Chinese soldiers gathered at the government offices in Runzhou District (Zhenjiang, Jiangsu) to demand answers over the alleged beating of a fellow veteran by government-hired thugs. The demonstrators used bricks and rods to hurt 65 officers and staff in three days. Some spouses of the soldiers were also beaten up by the police. [size=around 1000]

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Government of China (2017-) Hong Kong Special Administrative Region
ACTOR2: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
NOTES: On 22 June 2018, more than 100 residents surrounded the sealed Pak Tin Shopping Centre in Sham Shui Po District in Hong Kong to oppose to the clearance and reconstruction of the shopping centre. A district council member got into a scuffle with some Housing Department officials when he attempted to squeeze into the centre and stop the shop clearance. The police arrived and halted the conflict. The district council member claimed he sustained some injures from the scuffles. [size=more than 100]

On 22 June 2018, around 1000 retired Chinese soldiers gathered at the government offices in Runzhou District (Zhenjiang, Jiangsu) to demand answers over the alleged beating of a fellow veteran by government-hired thugs. The demonstrators used bricks and rods to hurt 65 officers and staff in three days. [size=around 1000]

On 23 June 2018, around 1000 retired Chinese soldiers gathered at the government offices in Runzhou District (Zhenjiang, Jiangsu) to demand answers over the alleged beating of a fellow veteran by government-hired thugs. The demonstrators used bricks and rods to hurt 65 officers and staff in three days. [size=around 1000]

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Government of China (2017-) Hong Kong Special Administrative Region
NOTES: On 25 June 2018, a district councillor led about a hundred local residents in a demonstration at the office of Pak Tin housing estate (Sham Shui Po district) to demand that the Housing Authority (HA) postponed the demolition of a shopping centre. While attempting to break into the HA office himself, he was physically handled by 5-6 security guards, and during the clash, the district councilor, his assistant, and 3 security guards were injured. A total of 5 persons were hospitalised. The district councilor was arrested eight days later on seven accumulative charges. [size=about a hundred]

On 30 June 2018, the eve of the Establishment Day of the CPC, thousands of Zhejiang rioters clashed with frontline police forces at the Qixing Town Government in Qixing Town, Nanhu District (Jiaxing city, Zhejiang) as they expressed their grievances over the injustices of forced evictions and involuntary land requisitions. The rioters threw rocks, bricks and barged into the government building, resulting in subsequent arrests. [size=thousands]

On 30 June 2018, more than 1000 residents affected by severe air and water pollution staged a demonstration at a waste treatment plant in Xiangyang town, Xiangfeng district (Harbin, Heilongjiang), against untreated wastewater discharge and groundwater contamination. The demonstration ended on 30 June when 40 residents were arrested by the local police, during which clashes were reported between demonstrators and the police. 20-30 people were still not released at the time of reporting on 7 July 2018, and some residents were also injured and hospitalized. They had been on site since 26 June, blocking the entrance and exit of the facility and assigning villagers to stay on guard 24 hours a day. [size=more than 1000]

SOURCE: Apple Daily Hong Kong; Epoch Times
NOTES: On 1 July 2018, thousands of residents from Qixin sub-district surrounded the Sub-district Office in Qixing sub-district of Nanhu district (Jiaxing, Zhejiang), threw stones and bricks towards the police officers who held the line to prevent them from approaching the governmental building. They later broke into the building and destroyed some properties. Special police injured several residents participating in the demonstration. The residents staged the demonstration after they found out that the sub-district government had given more compensation to holdout owners than to those who had agreed to land resumption terms. On 3 July 2018, more than 20 people in relation to this event were arrested. [size=thousands]

On 2 July 2018, as many as 100 migrant workers demonstrated in Zunyi, Guizhou to demand for wage arrears and vehicle and equipment rental fees owed by a private construction project, which appeared to have changed hands. They occupied the construction site with their vehicles and clashed with company staff and security guards. [size=as many as 100]

On 3 July 2018, workers suffering from pneumoconiosis continued to petition and demonstrate for the second consecutive day at Shenzhen Public Complaints and Proposals Administration in Futian District (Shenzhen, Guangdong), demanding for compensations. It was reported that there were some physical conflict between one demonstrator and the police. [size=unreported]

On 10 July 2018, 7 families were beaten up by groups sent by the government and property developers during an unannounced forced eviction and property seizure in Xixiao village of Haicheng district, Beihai, Guangxi. The Beihai Government's statement on Weibo reported that two villagers threw stones at law enforcement officers and injured many of them, and that a gun was found in one of the villagers' homes. The government claimed that the properties seized were unauthorized building works. Exact injuries and number of victims unknown. [size=two]

On 11 July 2018, residents were beaten up by groups sent by the government and property developers during an unannounced forced eviction and property seizure operation in Xixiao village of Haicheng district, Beihai, Guangxi. The Beihai Government's statement on Weibo reported that five villagers attacked law enforcers with knives and metal batons, resulting in 9 injuries, 5 of which were on the law enforcers' side. The government justified that the properties seized were unauthorized building works. More than 30 households were demolished, and 8 residents were hospitalized for injuries including concussions and bone fractures. [size=no report]

On 18 July 2018, a watermelon farmer and his two sons clashed with public security in Tan'er town of Chengguan district, Lanzhou due to recent violent treatment of watermelon farmers. One of the sons stabbed three public security personnel, resulting in one death and two injuries. [size=3]

ACTOR2: Police Forces of China (2012-) People's Armed Police
NOTES: On 26 July 2018, more than 200 homeowners petitioned at the Shaanxi People's Government in Xincheng district (Xi'an) for a redress of their decade-long grievances towards real estate developer Desheng, after the processing of their Premises Permit had been repeatedly delayed. Clashes between the demonstrators and the police, including riot police, took place, resulting in scratches and beatings, as well as 4 arrested. They were all later released within the same day. [size=more than 200]

On 31 July 2018, police launched rubber bullets at villagers in Fusui county, Guangxi during an operation to arrest individuals suspected of illegal fundraising and instigating villagers to oppose mining activities by local enterprises. According to government press release, around 200 villagers chased and beat up public security forces with sticks and stones as they were about to leave, resulting in over 10 injuries. [size=around 200]

Around 3 August 2018 (as reported), as many as 100 security guards created a roadblock and demonstrated in Taiyuan, Shanxi to demand for wage arrears owed by a state-owned construction project (Tianfeng Mianfen). Food delivery drivers were reportedly hit and injured by the rioters. [size=as many as 100]

On 11 August 2018, around 20 highway workers created rock blocks and gathered in Luchuan, Guangxi to demand for wage arrears owed by a private construction project. They blocked the construction site with trucks and private vehicles, and broken or ruined construction machinery. They continued to demonstrate until 14 August, when 30 public security officers took 26 workers back to the station, and detained 22 of them. [size=around 20]

On 12 August 2018, around 20 highway workers created rock blocks and gathered in Luchuan, Guangxi to demand for wage arrears owed by a private construction project. They blocked the construction site with trucks and private vehicles, and broken or ruined construction machinery. They continued to demonstrate until 14 August, when 30 public security officers took 26 workers back to the station, and detained 22 of them. [size=around 20]

On 13 August 2018, around 20 highway workers created rock blocks and gathered in Luchuan, Guangxi to demand for wage arrears owed by a private construction project. They blocked the construction site with trucks and private vehicles, and broken or ruined construction machinery. They continued to demonstrate until 14 August, when 30 public security officers took 26 workers back to the station, and detained 22 of them. [size=around 20]

On 14 August 2018, around 20 highway workers created rock blocks and gathered in Luchuan, Guangxi to demand for wage arrears owed by a private construction project. They blocked the construction site with trucks and private vehicles, and broke or ruined construction machinery. Demonstrations started on 11 Aug, and on 14 Aug, 30 public security officers took 26 workers back to the station, and detained 22 of them. [size=around 20]

On 20 August 2018, at night, several thousand veterans and citizens gathered in Meilu sub-district of Wuchuan city (Zhenjiang, Guangzhou), at the location where a veteran and his wife had been beaten up by personnel from the Urban Administrative and Law Enforcement Bureau (UALEB) earlier that day, to express their solidarity for the couple. The demonstrators surrounded police and UALEB officers and violent clashes ensued, and injured people were reported to have been taken away on stretchers. Authorites sent armoured vehicles to disperse the crowd, while the Vice Mayor of Wuchuan and the Secretary of the UALEB arrived on scene to pacify the situation. [size=several thousand]

On 21 August 2018, six construction workers were beaten with batons by their project contractors while demonstrating in Leshan, Sichuan and subsequently hospitalised. The were demanding for several months of wage arrears owed by a highway construction project (Renmu) under state-owned enterprise China Railway No.5 Engineering Group. Police forces arrived on the scene but did not participate in the violent clash that ensued on both sides. [size=at least six]

On 25 August 2018, citizens clashed with the police in Dabuba Village in Yazhou district (Sanya, Hainan), when police came by to investigate why the former had vandalized display boards at a questionnaire activity organized by an agriculture cultivation governing body earlier that day (this was because of a land dispute). Several citizens and policemen on each side were injured, and police cars were damaged to varying degrees. [size=at least several]

On 1 September 2018, parents demonstrated outside the headquarters of Leiyang Public Security Bureau (Leiyang, Hunan) to demand for the release of 5 people arrested earlier the same day for demonstrating against government plans to place students in private boarding schools. About 10 people were detained and later released, but about 600 people had gathered in the meantime. The demonstrators threw water bottles, bricks, fireworks, and petrol bottles at officials and police officers, wounding 30 of them and damaging the police building and vehicles. The clashes were brought under control early on the morning of 2 Sep, after 46 people were detained. [size=about 600]

On 5 September 2018, thousands of demonstrators clashed with hundreds of police at Guanshan boulevard (Hongshan, Wuhan) during a demonstration against the construction of a substation near their community. [size=thousands]

On 10 September 2018, about 2000 veterans petitioned for their legal rights at the Department of Civil Affairs of Sichuan Province located in Jinjiang District (Chengdu, Sichuan). During the petition, multiple police forces showed up and clashed with the veterans, both sides pushed and fought the other, and some of the veterans were wounded. Later on the same day, the veterans went on petitioning in front of the Provincial Government of Sichuan province, the police were again at the site and clashed with the veterans with fights and pushes, wounding some of the veterans. The police also used tear gas during the clash. [size=about 2000]

On 30 September 2018, Ping Du city (Qingdao, Shandong) witnessed demonstrations by more than 1000 veterans who said they had not been adequately compensated for their services. Across five days, 60 demonstrators attacked the police with fire extinguishers and rods, resulting in 34 people getting injured. Online reports anticipated that 3000 veterans from outside of Shandong would come to Pingdu to show their support. The city government responded that many veterans faked their injuries. [size=more than 1000]

On 1 October 2018, Ping Du city (Qingdao, Shandong) witnessed demonstrations by more than 1000 veterans who said they had not been adequately compensated for their services. Demonstrators reportedly attacked the police with fire extinguishers and rods. Across five days from 30 September to 4 October, a total of 34 people were reportedly injured. Online reports anticipated that 3000 veterans from outside of Shandong would come to Pingdu to show their support. The city government responded that many veterans faked their injuries. [size=more than 1000]

On 2 October 2018, Ping Du city (Qingdao, Shandong) witnessed demonstrations by more than 1000 veterans who said they had not been adequately compensated for their services. Demonstrators reportedly attacked the police with fire extinguishers and rods. Across five days from 30 September to 4 October, a total of 34 people were reportedly injured. Online reports anticipated that 3000 veterans from outside of Shandong would come to Pingdu to show their support. The city government responded that many veterans faked their injuries. [size=more than 1000]

On 3 October 2018, Ping Du city (Qingdao, Shandong) witnessed demonstrations by more than 1000 veterans who said they had not been adequately compensated for their services. Demonstrators reportedly attacked the police with fire extinguishers and rods. Across five days from 30 September to 4 October, a total of 34 people were reportedly injured. Online reports anticipated that 3000 veterans from outside of Shandong would come to Pingdu to show their support. The city government responded that many veterans faked their injuries. [size=more than 1000]

On 4 October 2018, a group of around 10 students went to the office of the Hong Kong Polytechnic University's in Kowloon City District (Hong Kong) and demanded an explanation of why the school had decided to take back the responsibility for managing the wall. The university leadership had used red paper to cover some parts of the university's Democracy Wall where there are pro-independence slogans. Multiple students and security personnel fell on the ground during a clash, with some security guards reportedly injured. [size=around 10]

On 4 October 2018, more than 1000 veterans demonstrated in Pingdu city (Qingdao, Shandong), stating that they had not been adequately compensated for their services. Demonstrators reportedly attacked the police with fire extinguishers and rods. Across five days from 30 September to 4 October, a total of 34 people were reportedly injured. Online reports anticipated that 3000 veterans from outside of Shandong would come to Pingdu to show their support. The city government responded that many veterans faked their injuries. [size=more than 1000]

On 6 October 2018, about 60 people, including veterans, got into clashes with police during a demonstration in front of the city government in Pingdu City (Qingdao, Shandong) to oppose the beating up of veterans by authorities early this month. Demonstrators used wooden sticks and fire extinguishers to attack police and smash up vehicles. Police responded using tear gas and batons. 8 people were taken away and 34 officers on duty were injured, 2 of whom sustained serious bone fractures. [size=about 60]

On 7 October 2018, between 200 and 600 veterans gathered in Pingdu City (Qingdao, Shandong) to demand for an apology from authorities over the beating up of a veteran by authorities early this month. 2000-3000 police officers were deployed and they used pepper water and batons to disperse the demonstrators. Clashes broke out between both parties and 7-8 veterans were injured. [size=200-600]

On 12 October 2018, students from universities in Beijing gathered in the Science and Technology University Beijing (Beijing) and had clashes with the university security guards over the deregistration of the Aiming student union of the university. Allegedly, the deregistration was due to the support towards the Jiashi labour movement in Shenzhen from the student union.[size=no report]

ACTOR2: Police Forces of China (2012-) People's Armed Police
NOTES: On 9 November 2018, around 1000 unemployed workers of Bo'en Guangxue factory and their families staged a demonstration in front of the factory in Huiyang district (Huizhou, Guangdong) over the layoff by the factory caused by the reduction of orders from Apple. They continued to mobilise until 12 November 2018. It was reported that physical clashes broke out between the workers and the police, and demonstrators threw chairs and debris during the demonstration. Dozens of people were injured, the armed police was allegedly mobilised to disperse them. [size=around 1000]

On 10 November 2018, a group of unidentified people cut off power from, smashed CCTVs, threw things, and poured human excrement into the residence of a petitioner who was foced evicted in Fengtai district (Beijing). [size=a group]

On 26 November 2018, hundreds of truck drivers demonstrated in front of the Erqi Memorial Tower in Erqi district (Zhengzhou, Henan) over the new government policies limiting the access of trucks to the urban area. The demonstrators held banners and the police clashed with the demonstrators. [size=hundreds]

On 15 December 2018, up to 1000 female workers from Yanghe Winery went on strike and staged a demonstration on Xuhuai Road in Sucheng District (Suqian, Jiangsu). The cause of the demonstration, according to one source, was the factory lowering the wage of workers without reducing their workload. However, according to a worker, it was because they did not get compensation after the company transformed into a joint-equity enterprise, and their shares of the company were taken away. It was reported that the workers were intercepted by local police and security guards along the way, but they still knocked down the iron gate of the factory and occupied the office building. [size=up to 1000]

On 16 December 2018, up to 1000 female workers from Yanghe Winery had their second day of demonstration and strike on Xuhuai Road in Sucheng District (Suqian, Jiangsu). The police forces and the workers had a clash, and the police used pepper spray. The demonstration and strike ended after the employer promised to increase workers' wages. [size=up to 1000]

SOURCE: Channel News Asia; South China Morning Post
NOTES: On 1 January, thousands of demonstrators marched from Causeway Bay in Wan Chai district to the Forecourt of the Central Government Office in Central and Western district for the city's annual New Year's Day rally organised by the Civil Human Rights Front. Demonstrators marched to express their dissatisfaction towards the government and to call for democratic reform in Hong Kong. Organisers estimate that the demonstration peaked at 5,500 people but police put the number at 3,200. CHRF did not allow pro-Beijing group Caring Hong Kong Power to be part of the march and confrontations broke out between the two parties. [Size=3200-5500]

ACTOR2: Police Forces of China (2012-) People's Armed Police
NOTES: On 7 January, more than 300 retired private, substitute, and kindergarten teachers demonstrated in front of the Xiangtan County Government Office in Yuetang to demand for pensions and financial compensation. Demonstrators carried banners, shouted slogans, and sang songs. About 100 officers from the Special Police and People's Armed Police clashed with demonstrators, four of whom were arrested. [size=more than 300]

SOURCE: Epoch Times; South China Morning Post; Radio Free Asia
NOTES: On 11 January 2019, thousands of parents gathered outside Licheng Health Centre and the Jinhu County Government in Jinhu county (Huai'an, Jiangsu) to demonstrate against the administration of expired vaccines to 145 children in Jinhu and the lack of a system for citizens to verify if vaccines had expired. Demonstrators clashed with police and surrounded and beat up a government official. More than 10 rioters were beaten up by police. [size=thousands]

Between 11 January and 13 January, nearly 100 villagers of the Sui minority ethnic group in Jichang Township, Duyun City demonstrated against the forced exhumation and cremation of bodies carried out by police. Demonstrators overturned police cars, smashed the cars with rocks, and threw stones at police, who retreated without arresting anyone or retaliating. [size=nearly 100]

ACTOR2: Police Forces of China (2012-) People's Armed Police
NOTES: On 12 January, as many as 100 teachers demonstrated in Jinghe New City, Xi Xian New Area, Weiyang, Xi'an [location coded as Weiyang] to demand for a performance bonus owed to them since the end of 2017. Demonstrators carried banners and shouted slogans in front of the government building and clashed with the People's Armed Police. [size=as many as 100]

Between 11 January and 13 January, nearly 100 villagers of the Sui minority ethnic group in Jichang Township, Duyun City demonstrated against the forced exhumation and cremation of bodies carried out by police. Demonstrators overturned police cars, smashed the cars with rocks, and threw stones at police, who retreated without arresting anyone or retaliating. [size=nearly 100]

Between 11 January and 13 January, nearly 100 villagers of the Sui minority ethnic group in Jichang Township, Duyun City demonstrated against the forced exhumation and cremation of bodies carried out by police. Demonstrators overturned police cars, smashed the cars with rocks, and threw stones at police, who retreated without arresting anyone or retaliating. [size=nearly 100]

On 15 January 2019, the Motor Transport Workers General Union staged a march against the government's tolerance of illegal car hire service from the Office of the Chief Executive to Justice Place in Central. Two taxis were smashed with a hammer and one rioter was injured. [size=no report]

ACTOR2: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
SOURCE: South China Morning Post; Radio Free Asia; AP
NOTES: On 23 January, about 8 demonstrators staged a flash demonstration organised by Demosisto leaders at the East Wing Forecourt of the Central Government Office in Central and Western District to demonstrate against the tabling of a bill that criminalises insulting the Chinese national anthem. Demonstrators mounted a banner at the flag post podium and got into minor scuffles with security, who removed the banner quickly. One security officer was injured during the scuffles and some plants were damaged by demonstrators. [size=about 8]

On 4 February, the home of a petitioner in Chengyang, Qingdao, including its windows and gates, was locked up from the outside with metal chains by members of anti-petitioning groups. Members of the vigilante group stood guard outside the family's home for at least eight days, preventing entry or exit. [size=no report]

On 11 February, several petitioners visiting the State Bureau for Letters and Calls in Xicheng were violently prevented from doing so by about 10 people from anti-petitioning groups. Many petitioners were violently taken away by rioters while several others had to be rescued from being corralled. [size=no report]

On 25 Feb 2019, up to 10,000 people demonstrated in Rongxian County (Zigong, Sichuan) after two fatal earthquakes happened that same day and called for an end to fracking activities in the area, which they believed were the cause of the earthquakes. Demonstrators clashed with police outside the county government and damaged the fence. [size=up to 10,000]

On 11 March 2019, the mother of a prominent human rights defender was roughly dragged about by a group of people keeping watch on her home as she was on her way out of her home in Wenjiang District (Chengdu, Sichuan). She was planning to visit her son in Mianyang city the next day but might not be able to make the journey after the incident. [size=no report] [women targeted: relatives of targeted groups or persons]

ACTOR2: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
SOURCE: Radio Free Asia; South China Morning Post
NOTES: On 15 March 2019, about 10 students from Lingnan University and members of Demosisto attempted to charge into the underground lobby of the East Wing Forecourt of the Central Government Office in Central and Western District (Hong Kong) to stage a sit-in demonstration to urge the government to withdraw the proposed Extradition Bill. They clashed with security personnel and only 5 female students managed to get inside, while the others continued demonstrating from the outside. Demonstrators shouted slogans and 9 of them were for detained by police for 6 hours. [size=about 10]

ACTOR2: Police Forces of China (2012-) People's Armed Police
NOTES: On 22 March 2019, about 700 villagers demonstrated at Sanhongqi Village, Beijiao Town in Shunde District (Foshan, Guangdong) in opposition to the selling off of their land at low prices by village officials. Demonstrators shouted slogans, carried banners, and got into clashes with riot police, who arrested about 60 of them. [size=about 700]

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: CHRF: Civil Human Rights Front; Demosisto; Students Independence Union
SOURCE: Wen Wei Po; Radio Free Asia; The Stand News
NOTES: On 31 March 2019, CHRF and legislators from the pro-democracy camp, including those from the Neo Democrats and People Power political parties, organized a march in opposition to the Extradition Bill proposed by the government, which is due to be tabled on 3 April 2019. Demonstrators, including members of Demosisto and pro-independence groups like Students Independence Union and Studentlocalism, carried banners, chanted slogans, demanded that the government withdraw the bill, and called for the resignation of Chief Executive Carrie Lam and Secretary for Security John Lee as they marched from the Southern Playground in Wan Chai District to the Central Government Complex in Central and Western District (Hong Kong). Demonstrators threw props at government buildings, set fire to props, and clashed with police. Organisers say that 12,000 people participated but police put the number at 5,200. [size=between 5,200 to 12,000]

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Demosisto; LSD: League of Social Democrats
ASSOC_ACTOR_2: DHKC: Defend Hong Kong Campaign; Hong Kong Island Federation
SOURCE: Radio Free Asia; Wen Wei Po
NOTES: On 9 April 2019, more than 300 demonstrators gathered outside the West Kowloon Magistrates' Courts in Sham Shui Po District (Hong Kong) to show their support and opposition to 9 leaders of the 2014 Occupy Central movement on trial. Demonstrators supporting the leaders included people from the League of Social Democrats and Demosisto, while about 50 people in opposition included members of Defend Hong Kong Campaign, Hong Kong Island Federation, and the Anti-Hong Kong Independence Alliance. Demonstrators from both sides shouted slogans, carried banners, sang songs, and clashed with each other. [size=more than 300]

On 16 April 2019, over 200 villagers demonstrated in Tanwei village of Liwan district (Guangzhou) to stop the demolition of vacant buildings that were now deemed illegal structures. They had a violent confrontation with the demolition personnel from the urban management bureau. Two female villagers were knocked down. Villagers continued to demonstrate until the early morning of 17 April 2019. Six villagers were arrested after they refused to disperse. [size=over 200]

Around 23 April 2019 (as reported), a Christian church at an unspecified village in Hohhot (Inner Mongolia) was demolished during Easter on the grounds of being illegally constructed. There were reported clashes between several hundred worshippers and the police forces and demolition staff. [size=several hundred]

On 26 April 2019, more than 700 people, including more than 100 parents and 600 students, staged the fourth-day demonstration at the Nanjing Application Technic School in Yuhuatai District (Nanjing City, Jiangsu Province). A large number of special police officers clashed with the demonstrators, after a person alleged to be a school employee pretended to be a rioter and shoved the police. The police dragged demonstrators onto cars and beat them up, resulting in a dozen demonstrators arrested or injured that day. A parent fainted on the ground during the clash. [size=more than 700]

On 11 May 2019, during a legislative assembly regarding the amendments to the extradition law, hundreds of people for and against the bill clashed with each other outside the Legislative Council in the Central and Western District of Hong Kong. Rioters from both sides shouted and beat the demonstrators from the opposite side. The police formed a human chain to separate the groups. It was reported that members of DHKC and the Zhenxi Group were among the demonstrators for supporting the bills. [size=hundreds]

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: BPA: Business and Professionals Alliance for Hong Kong; HKFTU: Hong Kong Federation of Trade Unions; Labour Group (China); DAB: Democratic Alliance for the Betterment and Progress of Hong Kong
ASSOC_ACTOR_2: CF: Council Front (Hong Kong); PP: People Power; DP: Democratic Party (Hong Kong); Neo Democrats; Civilians (China); Journalists (China)
NOTES: On 11 May 2019, at least 14 lawmakers for and against the proposed amendments to the extradition law clashed after several attempts to hold rival meetings on the same topic in the same meeting room at the Legislative Council in Admiralty in the Central and Western District of Hong Kong. Pro-Beijing lawmakers and pro-democracy lawmakers shouted, pushed and shoved each other in an adjoining hallway, resulting in at least 4 people, including members of Council Front, PP, HKFTU and journalists, falling to the ground. A pro-Beijing lawmaker, also a member of BPA, attempted to replace a DP lawmaker to preside over the meeting as the head of the Bills Committee. However, his microphone was seized by a Council Front lawmaker and a Neo Democrats lawmaker. During the scuffle, the Neo Democrats lawmaker fell off from a table and needed to be sent to the hospital immediately. At the end of the chaos, 4 pro-Beijing lawmakers, including members of HKFTU and DAB, were also injured. The two camps both reported that the opposite side attacked them. [size=at least 14]

On 21 May 2019, hundreds of employees holding banners demonstrated in front of a recently closed supermarket in Dengzhou City (Nanyang City, Henan Province) to demand for unpaid wage owed to them. The boss was present at the scene and 'bloody' clashes broke out between the two parties. A female employee who got injured became unconscious and needed to be sent to the hospital. [size=hundreds]

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Government of China (2017-) Hong Kong Special Administrative Region
NOTES: On 5 June 2019, after a discussion session at the Legislative Council in Admiralty (Central and Western district, Hong Kong) about the anti-extradition bill, many democratic legislative councillors surrounded the Secretary for Security to demand him to withdraw the bill and to step down. After the session, some democratic legislative councillors continued to shout slogans and displayed banners, barring the Secretary from leaving. During this period, there were reports of pushing and shoving between demonstrators and the security guards of Legislative Council. Some councillor and security guards from the Legislative Council were reportedly hurt during the clashes. [size=many]

ACTOR2: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
NOTES: On 7 June 2019, unidentified persons threw a Molotov Cocktail at the Happy Valley Police station near Causeway Bay (Wan Chai, Hong Kong) in a private car. Police later arrested four people. [size=at least 4]

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: CHRF: Civil Human Rights Front; Civilians (China); Demosisto; Five Demands Movement; Journalists (China); Students (China)
ACTOR2: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
SOURCE: Radio Free Asia; The Stand News; RTHK
NOTES: On 9 June 2019, between 240,000 and 1,030,000 people joined a march organised by CHRF from Victoria Park to the Government Headquarters in Admiralty (Central and Western district, Hong Kong) to oppose the extradition bill. The march was joined by students from various schools. Demonstrators shouted slogans. Police arrested 7 people during the demonstration, one of whom was involved in destruction of a street station, six were involved in a theft, and 1 in attacking a police officer. After the march, around 350 demonstrators clashed with the police outside the Government headquarters. They attempted to storm into the Legislative Council complex and threw bottles and metal barricades at police and pushed barricades while officers responded with pepper spray. 8 officers, some demonstrators and journalists were injured. Meanwhile, members from Demosisto staged a sit-in rally in the car park of the Legislative Council to demand a dialogue with the Chief Executive and the Head of the Security Bureau. 19 people were arrested during the incident. [size=240,000-1,030,000]

On 11 June 2019, 1 security guard and his two relatives demonstrated in Yanliang, Xi'an, Shaanxi to demand wage arrears owed to them by a property development company. They violently clashed with the police, leaving two of the officers injured. They were later subdued with tear gas and arrested the next day. [size=3]

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: CHRF: Civil Human Rights Front; Five Demands Movement
ACTOR2: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
NOTES: On 12 June 2019, as many as 10000 demonstrators echoed CHRF's call to paralyse traffic in Admiralty in an attempt to stall the second reading of the extradition bill in the Legislative Council in Admiralty (Central and Western district, Hong Kong). They rushed on Lung Wo Road and Harcourt Road to block traffic with barricades and railings in the morning. After the government announced that the second reading debate on the extradition bill had been postponed indefinitely, demonstrators still continued their demonstration. They shouted slogans demanding the withdrawal of the bill. Police dispersed the demonstrators with tear gas, pepper spray, rubber bullets, bean rounds bullets and batons, who responded by throwing water bottles and bricks at them. 22 police officers were reportedly injured and 11 people were arrested. The police's alleged excessive use of force and categorisation of the event as ''''riot'''' prompted the broader Five Demands Movement following this event (location coded as Hong Kong-Central and Western). [size=as many as 10,000]

On 21 June 2019, echoing Demosisto Joshua Wong's call, almost 10,000 demonstrators and members of Demosisto surrounded the Police Headquarters in Wan Chai (Hong Kong) to demand to have a dialogue with the Commissioner of Police, to withdraw the definition of anti-extradition bill demonstrations as 'riots' and to release arrestees unconditionally. Demonstrators threw eggs at the headquarters and set up barricades to block entrances to the headquarters. [size=almost 10,000]

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
NOTES: On 26 June 2019, following the CHRF rally in Central, around 5000 demonstrators gathered outside the Police Headquarters in Wan Chai (Hong Kong) to demand the 'release of the Commissioner of Police'. They shouted slogans, threw eggs at the walls and vandalised the gates. They also displayed a flag demanding the release of demonstrators arrested during previous anti-ELAB demonstrations. A police officer was arriving for his work shift when several demonstrators rounded him up then kicked and punched him. Some demonstrators also blocked the CCTV cameras with railings and umbrellas. They also blocked roads. [size=around 5000]

SOURCE: The News Lens; Radio Free Asia; Epoch Times
NOTES: On 28 June 2019, between as many as 1000 to 10000 people took to the streets in Xinzhou district (Wuhan, Hubei) demonstrating against the construction of a waste incineration power plant. They shouted slogans and held banners to express concerns regarding environmental pollution. It was reported that more than 1000 police were deployed, and there were clashes between demonstrators and the police. Some demonstrators were beaten up, resulting in one man being hospitalised. Some of them threw water bottles at police. [size=between as many as 1000 to 10000]

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Government of China (2017-) Hong Kong Special Administrative Region
NOTES: On 28 June 2019, a few hundred demonstrators demonstrated near the harbourfront in Central (Central and Western district, Hong Kong) against the rezoning of part of the harbourfront area to military land dedicated to the PLA. They shouted slogans and hung signs on the woven wire fence. Some of them, included a legislative councillor, cut the barbed wires of the site and entered the prohibited land and wrote banners in the area. Police arrived equipped with pepper water. The two sides had a stand-off for around an hour before the demonstrators retreated. [size=a few hundred]

ACTOR2: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
NOTES: On 30 June 2019, while walking along the Admiralty Centre Skyway in Western and Central District (Hong Kong) after leaving the Legislative Council, a Democratic Party member of the Legislative Council was surrounded by dozens of people who had participated in the demonstration organised by Politihk Social Strategic. Police had to intervene when they started attacking and berating him. He sustained injuries and was hospitalised after. [size=dozens]

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Former Police Forces of China (2012-); Government of China (2017-) Hong Kong Special Administrative Region
NOTES: On 30 June 2019, Politihk Social Strategic organised a demonstration at Tamar Park in Central and Western District (Hong Kong) in support of the police force. Participants included former senior police officials, retired police officers, and the deputy director of the Committee for the Basic Law. Organisers said 165,000 people participated but police put the number at 53,000. During the demonstration, dozens of people opposing the Extradition Bill also gathered at the same venue and got into clashes with the demonstrators and police had to break up the fights. [size=53,000-165,000]

ACTOR2: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
NOTES: On the morning of 1 July 2019, the 22nd anniversary of the return of Hong Kong to China, over 1000 demonstrators clashed with the police around Wan Chai, Hong Kong, where the flag-raising ceremony took place. Some demonstrators threw eggs and bricks at the police, who responded with pepper spray and sticks. There were injuries on both sides. 13 police were hurt by corrosive fluid thrown by the demonstrators. [size=over 1000]

ACTOR2: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
NOTES: On 1 July 2019, the 22nd anniversary of the return of Hong Kong to China, over 100 demonstrators opposing the Extradition Bill broke in and occupied the Legislative Council Complex in Admiralty with force after a standoff with the over 100 riot police for 8 hours. Riot police used pepper spray on the rioters to deter them from getting close to the building. The confrontation escalated as masked rioters broke into the facility after upturning metal gates, spray-painting its interior and defacing portraits of current and former LegCo presidents. Police appeared to retreat to areas deeper within the building as rioters entered. At least three Legislative Councillors requested the demonstrators not to attack the Legislative Building but failed. Two were hurt mildly. [size=over 100]

ACTOR2: Police Forces of China (2012-) People's Armed Police
SOURCE: Epoch Times; The News Lens; Radio Free Asia
NOTES: On 2 July 2019, between as many as 1000 to 10000 people took to the streets in the Xinzhou district (Wuhan, Hubei) and shouted slogans, demonstrating against the construction of a waste incineration power plant in Wuhan, Hubei province. Local riot police were deployed. There were clashes between the two sides, where demonstrators threw water bottles at officers and officers used batons to hit them in return. Several people were taken away by police officers and some were injured and sent to hospital. [size=between as many as 1000 to 10000]

ACTOR2: Police Forces of China (2012-) People's Armed Police
SOURCE: Epoch Times; The News Lens; Radio Free Asia
NOTES: On 3 July 2019, between as many as 1000 to 10000 people took to the streets in the Xinzhou district of Wuhan and shouted slogans, demonstrating against the construction of waste incineration facilities and a power plant in Wuhan, Hubei province. Local riot police were present. There were clashes between the two sides. Several people were taken away by police officers and some were injured. [size=between as many as 1000 to 10000]

ACTOR2: Police Forces of China (2012-) People's Armed Police
SOURCE: Radio Free Asia; Epoch Times; The News Lens
NOTES: On 4 July 2019, between as many as 1000 to a few thousand people took to the streets in Xinzhou district (Wuhan, Hubei) and shouted slogans, demonstrating against the construction of a waste incineration power plant. Local riot police were present. There were clashes between the two sides. Three coaches of people were taken away by police officers and detained in a primary school. Some demonstrators were reportedly injured. The police demanded that all businesses be barred from business after dark, citing suspected terrorism. [size=between as many as 1000 to a few thousand]

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: DAB: Democratic Alliance for the Betterment and Progress of Hong Kong
NOTES: On 4 July 2019, about 100 people surrounded a district councillor from the Democratic Alliance for the Betterment and Progress of Hong Kong and her assistant in Tin Shui Wai, Yuen Long, in opposition to her collecting public opinion on the 'violent storming of the Legislature'. Mistaken as a volunteer of the pro-Beijing party, one citizen was mildly hurt by the crowd. [size=about 100]

ACTOR2: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
SOURCE: Ming Pao; Radio Free Asia; HKFP
NOTES: On 7 July 2019, 56,000-230,000 people participated in a march to the West Kowloon High-Speed Rail Station in Yau Tsim Mong district (Hong Kong) (coded to Hong Kong - Yau Tsim Mong), which was initiated by online dissenters to spread awareness of the anti-ELAB movement to mainland tourists, and to urge the government to fulfill their 'five demands'. Many people refused to leave after reaching the destination at around 4pm. Some of them got into confrontations with police from across road barriers and directed lasers at them. At night, after the march, a few hundred demonstrators gathered at the tourist area of Canton Road. As they attempted to proceed to the Tsim Sha Tsui Ferry Pier, police formed a chain to block them. Clashes broke out, resulting in injuries and several arrests. At 10 p.m., the demonstrators proceeded to Mong Kok. Police began efforts to disperse them around 11 p.m. and further clashes, injuries, and arrests ensued. A female passerby was rounded up by at least three demonstrators, choked, bruised and sexually assaulted. She was targeted for taking photos of the demonstration and mistaken to be an undercover officer. The 'clearance operation' ended around 2 a.m. the following day. [size=56,000-230,000]

On 10 July 2019, there was a confrontation between a group of middle-aged men and some youngsters with opposite political opinions at the 'Lennon Wall' message board outside the Yau Tong MTR station in Kowloon, which included verbal abuse and physical scuffles, drawing around 200 people to the scene and police making two arrests. [size=2 groups]

ACTOR2: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
SOURCE: Radio Free Asia; Ta Kung Pao; HKFP
NOTES: On 13 July 2019, 30,000 people (police quoted turnout at 4,000) attended a 'reclaim Sheung Shui' demonstration in Sheung Shui in Northern district (Hong Kong) to oppose parallel traders from China, who are accused of littering the neighbourhood and distorting the local economy. Participants got into clashes with police and used umbrellas and sticks to beat up four police officers. Police used pepper spray and batons to disperse demonstrators. At least 16 officers were injured, some of whom were suspectedly attacked with corrosive liquid. There were passers-by who were beaten up by demonstrators after being accused of taking pictures of the demonstrators' faces. [size=4000-30000]

ACTOR2: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
SOURCE: Ta Kung Pao; Radio Free Asia
NOTES: On 14 July 2019, 115,000 people attended the Anti-Extradition Bill march in Sha Tin (police estimated the turnout to be 28,000) to ask the government to respond to people's demands for democracy. Police fired pepper spray and engaged in physical fight with around 100 demonstrators inside the Sha Tin mall, causing injuries of many people. 47 demonstrators were arrested. 28 people were sent to hospital. 13 of them were police officers. [size=28000-115000]

On 15 July 2019, around 10 people gathered at the office of a pro-democratic district/legislative councillor in Lok Fu, Kowloon to condemn the councillor for abusing his power as a councillor and obstructing the police from performing their duties during recent demonstrations. A few dozens of people were drawn to the scene, booing the demonstrators. Both sides engaged in verbal and physical clashes. Police intervened to stop the clashes. [size=around 10]

As reported on 18 July 2019, as many as 300 delivery drivers demonstrated against pay cut by a cargo company by blocking roads and bridges in Ningbo, Zhejiang. They demanded pay increase. Some drivers clashed with the police, with two being taken away. [size=as many as 300]

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: CHRF: Civil Human Rights Front; Five Demands Movement
ACTOR2: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
SOURCE: Radio Free Asia; Ta Kung Pao; HKFP
NOTES: On 21 July 2019, around 430,000 anti-government demonstrators (police estimated the turnout to be 138,000) participated in a march organised by the Civil Human Rights Front from Wan Chai to Sai Wan to demand that their 'five demands' be met. Some demonstrators occupied roads outside the legislature and government headquarters in Admiralty as police retreated. They chanted slogans and created makeshift barricades, while some also spray painted over CCTV cameras and threw eggs at the Legislative Council building. Police dispersed the crowd with tear gas after dark. A man driving through the scene attempted to argue with the black-clad demonstrators blocking the roads, but was then beaten up. [size=138000-430000]

On 21 July 2019, at least 10 people participated in a demonstration in Lianzhou city, Qingyuan in Guangdong province against water pollution allegedly produced by a mining company as it carried out stealth mining. These rioters used sticks to break police cars. The city government had set up an investigation unit to look into this matter. [size=at least 10]

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Government of China (2017-) Hong Kong Special Administrative Region; Lawyers (China)
NOTES: On 22 July 2019, anti-ELAB demonstrators and students vandalised LegCo member and lawyer Junius Ho Kwan-yiu's branch office at Tsuen Fung Centre, Tsuen Wan district (Hong Kong) after a white-clad mob attacked demonstrators and rail passengers at the Yuen Long MTR station the night before (known later as the '7.21 incident.') They smashed windows and wrecked property. The act took place after the pro-Beijing lawmaker was filmed - in a video widely shared on social media - shaking hands with men in white outfits on the night of the incident. [size=no report]

On 24 July 2019, a large number of citizens demonstrated at the lobby of the MTR Headquarters in Kowloon Bay, Kwun Tong, asking the MTR to disclose the CCTV footage of the Yuen Long West Rail Station where the 21 July attack happened as well as communication records of the train staff, the control centre, and the police. There were mild clashes between some demonstrators and MTR staff. [size=a large number]

ACTOR2: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
SOURCE: Ta Kung Pao; Radio Free Asia
NOTES: On 28 July 2019, a large number of people attended a demonstration at the Chater Garden in Central to rally against the police's recent clearance operation and use of excessive force against anti-ELAB demonstrators. Demonstrators later marched to China's Liaison Office in Sheung Wan. There were confrontations between the riot police and the demonstrators. Demonstrators threw bricks and used tear gas at the police, who responded with more tear gas. Four people were injured. Demonstrators also set fires at multiple locations in Sheung Wan. 49 people were arrested, among whom 44 were charged with rioting. [size=at least 49]

On 28 July 2019, a large number of people attended a demonstration at the Chater Garden in Central to rally against the police's recent clearance operation and use of excessive force against demonstrators. Demonstrators later marched to the police headquarters in Wan Chai. They occupied roads around Causeway Bay, demolishing road barriers to create barricades. On the same day, thousands of demonstrators joined a spontaneous anti-government demonstration and marched from Central to Causeway Bay. They occupied roads and shouted slogans and set up barricades. No police intervention. [size=thousands]

ACTOR2: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
SOURCE: HKFP; Ta Kung Pao; Radio Free Asia
NOTES: On 30 July 2019, several hundred demonstrators surrounded the Kwai Chung police station in Kwai Tsing District (Hong Kong) in support of 44 demonstrators charged with rioting earlier in the day. Demonstrators occupied a section of the road outside the police station and shouted slogans. Police arrived at the scene to try to disperse demonstrators, but retreated after demonstrators scolded and confronted them. Later, demonstrators threw eggs and random items at more than 10 riot police, who used sticks and pepper sprays to disperse the demonstrators. The Kwai Chung police chief was seriously injured. He once pointed a gun at the demonstrators but did not shoot. At least five police officers were burnt by acid bombs thrown by demonstrators. [size=several hundred]

ACTOR2: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
SOURCE: Channel News Asia; Radio Free Asia; Wen Wei Po; HKFP
NOTES: On 3 August 2019, 120,000 people took to the streets in Mong Kok and marched towards Anchor Street Playground in Tai Kok Tsui to demonstrate against the Extradition Bill. Some demonstrators did not follow the designated route, and headed directly to Mong Kok and Tsim Sha Tsui instead. Some demonstrators moved barricades into the toll plaza of the Cross-Harbour Tunnel in Hung Hom, blocking vehicles. Police fired tear gas and pepper spray to disperse the crowd. Many demonstrators, armed with wooden sticks, were throwing bricks and glass bottles. Unknown number of arrests were made in the clearing of streets. More than 1,000 demonstrators surrounded the Tsim Sha Tsui Police Station, throwing bricks and debris, smashing vehicles in the police station car park, and setting fire around the station. [size=120,000]

ACTOR2: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
NOTES: On 4 August 2019, anti-extradition bill demonstrators rallied in Tseung Kwan O in Sai Kung, Hong Kong to call for the government to respond to people's political demands. Organisers said 150,000 people participated in the rally. Demonstrators demolished roadside railings and set up roadblocks, while some besieged Tseung Kwan O Police Station and threw bricks and debris at the police station, breaking glass windows and prompting officers to emerge with dogs. [size=150,000]

ACTOR2: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
NOTES: On 4 August 2019, anti-extradition bill demonstrators rallied in the Western District of Hong Kong to call for the government to respond to people's political demands. Demonstrators set up roadblocks and burnt bins to block the roads. Police dispersed demonstrators with tear gas. [size=no report]

ACTOR2: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
NOTES: On 5 August 2019, hundreds of anti-extradition bill demonstrators blocked the roads and set up barricades near Admiralty in an attempt to paralyse the city of Hong Kong to pressure the SAR government to respond to people's political demands. Police dispersed demonstrators with tear gas. Meanwhile, a moving taxi rushed towards the demonstrators who had gathered at Tamar Park, Admiralty. Some demonstrators were hurt. The taxi escaped quickly. [size=hundreds]

ACTOR2: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
NOTES: On 5 August 2019, hundreds of anti-extradition bill demonstrators blocked the roads and set up barricades near Sha Tin in an attempt to paralyse the city of Hong Kong to pressure the SAR government to respond to people's political demands. Hundreds of demonstrators planted themselves in the lobby of the Sha Tin New Town Plaza. Police dispersed with tear gas. On the same day, a few hundred anti-extradition bill demonstrators besieged Sha Tin Police Station, demolishing railings and blocked roads. They got into an altercation with a driver, who pulled out an axe and argued with the demonstrators. With intervention from the people around, the demonstrators let the driver leave. No injury reported. [size=hundreds]

ACTOR2: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
NOTES: On 5 August 2019, hundreds of anti-extradition bill demonstrators blocked the roads and set up barricades near Tai Po in an attempt to paralyse the city of Hong Kong to pressure the SAR government to respond to people's political demands. Police dispersed demonstrators with tear gas. [size=hundreds]

ACTOR2: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
NOTES: On 5 August 2019, hundreds of anti-extradition bill demonstrators blocked the roads and set up barricades near Tsuen Wan in an attempt to paralyse the city of Hong Kong to pressure the SAR government to respond to people's political demands. Police dispersed demonstrators with tear gas. [size=hundreds]

ACTOR2: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
NOTES: On 5 August 2019, hundreds of anti-extradition bill demonstrators blocked the roads and set up barricades near Wong Tai Sin in an attempt to paralyse the city of Hong Kong to pressure the SAR government to respond to people's political demands. Police dispersed demonstrators with tear gas. [size=hundreds]

ACTOR2: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
NOTES: On 5 August 2019, hundreds of anti-extradition bill demonstrators blocked the roads and set up barricades near Mong Kok in an attempt to paralyse the city of Hong Kong to pressure the SAR government to respond to people's political demands. Police dispersed demonstrators with tear gas. Demonstrators were seen taking down the China national flag on the Tsim Sha Tsui waterfront and throwing it into the sea. [size=hundreds]

ACTOR2: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
NOTES: On 5 August 2019, as many as 100 demonstrators gathered in Tin Shui Wai in Yuen Long in opposition to the sexual harassment of a female demonstrator by a police officer during a previous demonstration, where a group of male officers removed the female demonstrator by grabbing her limbs. Demonstrators surrounded the Tin Shui Wai Police Station and threw stones at the riot police as well as the police station. Some demonstrators were injured. Police dispersed demonstrators with rubber and metal bullets and fired at least 50-60 cannisters of tear gas. 76 demonstrators were arrested in Tin Shui Wai for 'illegal assembly'. [size=as many as 100]

On 5 August 2019, a car rushed towards anti-extradition bill demonstrators blocking roads with barricades in Yuen Long. The driver was reportedly tied up by some demonstrators before driving his car towards them. When the police came, both the driver and the injured demonstrators had left the scene. [size=no report]

ACTOR2: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
NOTES: On 5 August 2019, hundreds of anti-extradition bill demonstrators blocked the roads and set up barricades near Tuen Mun in an attempt to paralyse the city of Hong Kong to pressure the SAR government to respond to people's political demands. Police dispersed demonstrators with tear gas. [size=hundreds]

SOURCE: Ming Pao; Radio Free Asia; Wen Wei Po
NOTES: On 10 August 2019, over 1000 anti-extradition bill demonstrators joined an unauthorised march in Tai Po against the government's handling of the now suspended extradition bill. Demonstrators blocked roads and faced off the police on a road near the police station. Some demonstrators threw eggs at a pro-Beijing district councillor's office and damaged the outside of the office. The crowd dispersed without clashes. Many shops were closed. [size=over 1000]

ACTOR2: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
NOTES: On 10 August 2019, a group of anti-extradition bill demonstrators staged a flash rally near Tsim Sha Tsui Police Station, blocking roads, setting fire, and laying siege to the police station opposing the police's arrest of a woman near an MTR station. They also blocked the cross-Harbour tunnel with barricades. Riot police dispersed demonstrators with tear gas. [size=no report]

ACTOR2: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
NOTES: On 10 August 2019, a group of anti-extradition bill demonstrators set up barricades in Tsuen Wan to disturb traffic. Riot police dispersed demonstrators with tear gas. [size=no report]

ACTOR2: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
NOTES: On 10 August 2019, a group of anti-extradition bill demonstrators blocked roads in Tai Wai and Tai Po Highway near Sha Tin with railings and bicycles. Riot police dispersed demonstrators with tear gas. [size=no report]
On 10 August 2019, a group of anti-extradition bill demonstrators surrounded Ngau Tau Kok Police Station in Kwun Tong. They blocked the roads nearby and damaged police signboards. [size=no report]

ACTOR2: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
SOURCE: Ta Kung Pao; Radio Free Asia
NOTES: On 11 August 2019, a group of anti-extradition bill demonstrators gathered at Tsim Sha Tsui Police Station in Yau Tsim Mong district (Hong Kong) and threw smoke bombs at the police, who dispersed them with tear gas. One first aider was injured. Police said that one armed officer was severely injured in his legs by a gas bomb thrown by demonstrators, and was subsequently hospitalised. One female demonstrator was shot in the eye. The identity of the shooter has not been verified. 29 people have been arrested. [size=at least 29]

ACTOR2: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
NOTES: On 11 August 2019, a group of anti-extradition bill demonstrators gathered at the police headquarters in Wan Chai and threw gas bombs at the police, setting fire to things. Riot police fired tear gas at the demonstrators. [size=no report]

ACTOR2: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
NOTES: On 11 August 2019, a group of anti-extradition law demonstrators blocked the entrance to the Quarry Bay MTR station in the Eastern district of Hong Kong with demolished railings. Riot police formed a defence line outside the station. Some demonstrators headed to Tai Koo in MTR, and riot police followed them into Tai Koo and fired tear gas and pepper-spray projectile at them in a close distance inside Tai Koo MTR station. Police arrested at least six people. [size=no report]

ACTOR2: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
NOTES: On 11 August 2019, as many as 1000 anti-extradition bill demonstrators joined an unauthorised march in Sham Shui Po and marched to Cheung Sha Wan. Demonstrators blocked roads, set up barricades, and surrounded the Sham Shui Po Police Station. Riot police dispersed demonstrators with tear gas and arrested some of them. [size=as many as 1000]

ACTOR2: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
NOTES: On 11 August 2019, a group of anti-extradition bill demonstrators gathered at Kwai Chung Police Station in Kwai Tsing. Riot police formed a line of defence inside the MTR station. Demonstrators shot fire hoses and fire extinguishers at the police officers, who fired tear gas back at them. Some demonstrators retreated to a plaza near the MTR station and confronted the police. Some people were feeling unwell during the confrontation. [size=no report]

ACTOR2: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
NOTES: On 13 August 2019, a group of demonstrators attended a sit-in demonstration at the Hong Kong International Airport in Chek Lap Kok to rally against the introduction of the Extradition Law and to call on the government to respond to people's five demands. Some demonstrators clashed with international visitors verbally. All flights departing after 4:30 pm were cancelled as a result of the demonstration. Chaotic scenes broke out as police attempted to escort a man accused to be an undercover agent from mainland China out of the departures hall who had been surrounded by demonstrators. Police used pepper spray to disperse the crowd. Demonstrators tried to prevent police vehicles from leaving by throwing trolleys into the road, damaging the cars and hurling abuse at officers. Multiple people were injured. Another stand-off happened when a mainland Chinese man was accused of pretending to be a journalist. [size=no report]

ACTOR2: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
SOURCE: The Stand News; Radio Free Asia
NOTES: On 14 August 2019, around 700 demonstrators held a paper-burning demonstration in Sham Shui Po on the occasion of the traditional Chinese hungry ghost festival to rally against police brutality at anti-government demonstrators. This resulted in police dispersing demonstrators with tear gas. Demonstrators burnt joss paper, chanted and shone laser pens into the Sham Shui Po Police Station complex. Some demonstrators reportedly attacked the police with marbles. Local residents complained about the use of tear gas. [size=around 700]

On 17 August 2019, a group of anti-extradition bill demonstrators joined the 'Reclaim To Kwa Wan-Hung Hom' march from To Kwa Wan to Whampoa near Tsim Sha Tsui to demand the government to solve the community issues brought by an excessive number of mainland tourists in the region and to condemn police brutality. The branch offices of pro-Beijing parties DAB and HKFTU were vandalised, and demonstrators hurled eggs at the offices. They placed pineapples, a metaphor for homemade explosives, outside HKFTU's office, reflecting their role during the Hong Kong 1967 leftist riots. Some demonstrators then moved to Mong Kok and besieged the Mong Kok police station. Demonstrators shouted slogans and set barricades to block roads in Mong Kok. Demonstrators backed off as riot police came. [size=no report]

ACTOR2: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
NOTES: On 21 August 2019, about 1000 masked demonstrators dressed in black demonstrated at Yuen Long MTR station in Yuen Long against police's selective arrest and to remember the victims of the 21 July Yuen Long mob attacks.
