NOTES: On 18 May 2020, pro-democracy legislators demonstrated during a meeting at the Legislative Council in Central and Western District (Hong Kong) (coded as Hong Kong - Central and Western), after Chan Kin-por (chairperson of the LegCo Finance Committee) had taken his position to preside over the meeting 45 minutes before the start. The legislators used a massive black cloth to surround the podium as a symbol of the 'black box operation' coordinated by the pro-establishment camp. Several pro-establishment legislators (including one from the DAB) rushed down to try to remove the black cloth. During the demonstration, one Democratic Party legislator tried to break through the cordon of security guards surrounding the podium, but was lifted by 4 security guards and dragged onto the ground. He was later diagnosed with a chest injury from being kicked in the chest during the commotion. Pro-democracy legislators continued to chant slogans questioning the authority of Chan Kin-por while pro-establishment legislators expressed support for Chan Kin-por. 15 out of 20 pro-democracy lawmakers were expelled from the meeting for clashing with security guards and two of the guards were injured. The remaining lawmakers went on to vote for a new chairperson and Starry Lee from the DAB was re-elected as chairperson. [size=at least 15]

On 23 May 2020, 6 unidentified persons assaulted 3 people (2 men and 1 woman) at a 'Lennon Wall' at the North District Town Hall in North District (Hong Kong). It was reported that the group of 3 people confronted the other group of 6 as they were putting up posters on the Lennon Wall. Both groups got into an altercation due to political differences, with some pushing and shoving, before the group of 6 people attacked the other group with umbrellas and bicycles. They escaped after the assault. The group of 3 sustained injuries in their shoulders and arms. [size=6]

ACTOR2: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
SOURCE: South China Morning Post; HK01; Ming Pao
NOTES: On 24 May 2020, thousands of demonstrators held a 'Anti-evil Law' rally in Causeway Bay, Wan Chai District (Hong Kong) against the proposed enactment of the national security law by the Chinese central government, to be tabled on 28 May 2020. They also demonstrated against the national anthem law, which was due to be tabled for a second reading on 27 May 2020. Demonstrators held banners and chanted slogans 'Hong Kong independence is the only way out'. They occupied streets around Causeway Bay, blocking roads with debris and setting fire to the debris. They also threw umbrellas, bricks at the police, and threw glass bottles down from the roof of Happy Mansion. A mob also smashed the glass windows of a retail store. Pepper balls were fired by the police in response. Tensions escalated along Canal Road where the police fired water cannon at demonstrators after they attempted to barricade the street. Tear gas was also fired outside the Hysan Place shopping centre. A lawyer was reportedly beaten by demonstrators with umbrellas on his head and torso, after he argued with demonstrators as they created roadblocks. Another woman was reportedly beaten after attempting to clear a roadblock. A total of 19 people were reportedly injured and sent to the hospital. 4 police officers injured, after being hit by bricks thrown by demonstrators. 193 people were arrested throughout the day. [size=thousands]

ACTOR2: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
SOURCE: South China Morning Post; Inmediahk.net; Ming Pao; The Stand News; HK01
NOTES: On 27 May 2020, between hundreds and nearly 1000 people demonstrated in several locations in Central and Western District (Hong Kong), as part of the 'three strikes' campaign held in several districts across Hong Kong on the same day, to oppose the legislation of the national security law. In the morning, about 30 students held a sit-in demonstration at St Paul's College, on the first day of reopening of school for upper secondary students. At noon, people gathered at Landmark shouting slogans, before walking out onto the streets. Demonstrators then raised umbrellas and chanted slogans such as 'Liberate Hong Kong, revolution of our time', 'Five demands, not one less'. Nearly 100 police officers were present and fired pepper balls at the demonstrators. Nearly 1000 people later walked out and occupied Pedder Street and shouted slogans. Riot police again fired several pepper balls to disperse the crowd. Demonstrators continued to throw traffic cones, trash cans and metal barriers to block the roads. According to the police, about 30 people were arrested in Central by 1pm, with a total of 396 people arrested in the demonstrations held across Hong Kong (including 180 students and 80 minors). [size=between hundreds and nearly 1000]

SOURCE: HK01; Ming Pao; South China Morning Post; The Stand News; RTHK
NOTES: On 27 May 2020, demonstrators gathered at Langham Place in Yau Tsim Mong District (Hong Kong), as part of the 'three strikes' campaign held in several districts across Hong Kong on the same day, to oppose the legislation of the national security law. They blocked roads around Nathan Road, placing several street signs on the road and held up the gesture calling for the five demands. At one point, demonstrators formed a line of defence with opened umbrellas to advance towards the police's line of defence. They also set up road blocks using water barriers and iron barriers on Fa Yuen Street. The demonstration in the district continued into the night as demonstrators blocked roads on several streets in the area, setting fire to debris and garbage in the middle of the streets. Gas canisters were thrown into the fire at one point, causing a series of explosions. About 100 demonstrators also walked onto Nathan Road to block roads. It was reported that water cannon trucks and armoured vehicles were deployed to the scene. A total of 396 people arrested in the demonstrations held across Hong Kong (including 180 students and 80 minors). [size=at least about 100]

On 27 May 2020, about 50 proprietors demonstrated outside the management office of the Tsuen Wan Industrial Center in Tsuen Wan District (Hong Kong), calling on the management to handle maintenance matters in an open and transparent manner (after the contractor which was previously handling maintenance works liquidated earlier in January 2020). They held up banners and slogans, requesting to be allowed to sit in for the owners' corporation (OC) meeting. It was reported that there were scuffles between the demonstrators and members of the OC, and a demonstrator was pushed to the ground by OC members. The police were called to the scene and a riot police officer came to understand the situation. [size=about 50]

On 27 May 2020, more than 10 black-clad people gathered in On Chit Street and Tai Pak Tin St in Kwai Tsing District (Hong Kong), setting fire to garbage bins and debris before quickly fleeing the scene. Before that, unidentified persons threw a fence onto the railway track at Kwai Hing MTR Station. These were likely to be part of the broader 'three strikes' demonstrations held across Hong Kong on the same day, to oppose the enactment of the national anthem law and national security law. [size=more than 10]

ACTOR2: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
NOTES: On 4 June 2020, more than 200 people gathered outside Langham Place in Yau Tsim Mong District (Hong Kong), in commemoration of the 31st anniversary of the 1989 Tiananmen Square Incident. Many people held placards, sang songs, and chanted slogans calling for Hong Kong independence. Around 9pm, as people exited the scene, some demonstrators attempted to block Argyle Street by throwing objects onto the street. Several plainclothes police officers emerged from the crowd to push demonstrators onto the grounds, before firing pepper spray towards the crowd who hurled water bottles and debris at them. More than 50 riot police then arrived at the scene to cordon off parts of the thoroughfare. 4 men were arrested. Earlier at 7pm, about 30 people also held a candlelight vigil at the Hong Kong Cultural Centre. [size=more than 200]

ACTOR2: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
NOTES: On 12 June 2020, over 100 people gathered at Langham Place in Yau Tsim Mong District (Hong Kong), chanting slogans and singing the anti-ELAB anthem 'Glory to Hong Kong'. The police then cordoned off the perimeter of Langham Place. Demonstrators also gathered at New Century Plaza, singing 'Glory to Hong Kong' and shouting slogans at people dining at Urban Cafe Commune not to patronize pro-establishment 'blue shops'. Police continued to warn demonstrators to leave and reportedly subdued one person at Portland Street. Many people were arrested at 8.30pm. The police reported that someone threw a hard object from a height at the police station on Shantung Street. The demonstration was held in commemoration of the first anniversary of the first major police clashes during the anti-ELAB demonstration on 12 June 2019. The police reported that a total of 43 people were arrested (28 men and 15 women) for the demonstrations held across Hong Kong in the evening. [size=over 100]

On 29 June 2020, 100-200 villagers demonstrated in Wayao Village in Changping District (Beijing) against the forced demolition of their villagers. During the demonstration, villagers blocked the entry point into their village, chanted slogans, threw rocks and spray fire extinguishers towards thousands of private security personnel and armed police from the public security bureau. The police and security personnel beat up demonstrators and fired pepper spray towards the crowd. Many people were reportedly injured and bleeding. A female demonstrator was reportedly pushed to the ground by the police, who then stepped on her, causing injuries in her leg. More than a dozen people were arrested. [size=100-200]

ACTOR2: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
NOTES: On 1 July 2020, thousands of people staged a demonstration in Wan Chai District (Hong Kong), to oppose the newly enacted national security law, which came into effect on the same day. They chanted anti-ELAB and pro-independence slogans around Wan Chai and Causeway Bay throughout the entire day. During the demonstration, demonstrators also blocked roads, set up makeshift barricades, while others set fire to debris they threw on the streets, and smashed the storefront of pro-Beijing businesses. Demonstrators also dug up bricks and placed them in the middle of Percival Street, before riot police threw handheld tear gas canisters to disperse the crowd. A water cannon, tear gas, pepper spray were also used during the demonstration to disperse crowd. A police officer was stabbed in his arm by a demonstrator while he was attempting to give chase to another suspect. Three other police officers were injured after a demonstrator rode his motorcycle into them. A total of 370 people were arrested throughout the day, with 10 people charged under the national security law. [size=thousands]

On 6 July 2020, six workers demonstrated in Taiyuan prefecture (Shanxi) regarding a labour dispute with a construction state-owned enterprise. They blocked the entrance of Taiyuan Bali Haide Park, and assaulted police officers when they arrived to mediate the situation. All six workers were arrested for criminal or administrative detention. [size=6]

Around 14 July 2020, a large number of residents of Xihongmen town, Daxing district (Beijing) rioted against the police due to dissatisfaction regarding fees for an entrance permit in and out of Xihongmen, which residents had to apply to move in and out of the town as part of the new coronavirus lockdown measures. They attempted to break through the entrance checkpoint, and shouted slogans against the fee collection. [size=a large number]

On 4 August 2020, employees of private farmland management enterprise Dawu Group were assaulted by a large number of public security officers when attempting block the demolition of their office in Wuzhuang village of Xushui district (Baoding, Hebei). State-owned farm from Xushui district sent people to demolish Dawu's office, who clashed with workers who came to stop the demolition. Dawu employees were beaten by riot police who arrived on the scene to intervene, and assaulted with tear gas and chili water. Many Dawu employees were injured and hospitalised. [size=no report]

On 7 August 2020, thousands of people staged a demonstration at the Shaoyang City People's Government in Daxiang District (Shaoyang, Hunan) against a government campaign to ban electric vehicles, bicycles and motorcycles. The week-long dissatisfaction turned into a riot, with demonstrators blocking and damaging officials' vehicles, and assaulting traffic police officers. Many were arrested. Authorities announced a suspension of the ban immediately afterwards. [size=thousands]

On 31 August 2020, several hundred ethnic Mongolian students who were participating in a boycott broke through the entrance of a Mongolian middle school in Naiman Banner (Tongliao, Inner Mongolia) while demonstrating against a national-level state policy to replace Mongolian with Mandarin Chinese as the medium of instruction for three subjects in elementary and middle schools for minority groups across the region (and five other provinces) starting with the immediate fall semester. Government curfews were imposed across various regions of Tongliao prefecture, forbidding cars and pedestrians from congregating publicly on the streets. [size=several hundred]

Around 31 August 2020, several hundred ethnic Mongolian parents gathered at a school in Jarud Banner (Tongliao, Inner Mongolia), and demonstrated against a national-level state policy to replace Mongolian with Mandarin Chinese as the medium of instruction for three subjects in elementary and middle schools for minority groups across the Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region (and five other provinces) starting with the immediate fall semester. They came to demand the release of their children, as large-scale student boycotts, strikes and demonstrations spread across the region. Clashes between the parents and several hundred riot police were recorded. [size=several hundred]

ACTOR2: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
SOURCE: The Stand News; Wen Wei Po; Inmediahk.net; RTHK; HK01; Radio Free Asia; Ming Pao
NOTES: On 6 September 2020, some demonstrators created roadblocks, and threw hard objects like cans, umbrellas and bottles at the police in Yau Tsim Mong district (Hong Kong). Police officers released pepper bombs, affecting nearby hawkers. On the same day, many demonstrations took place in the district against the enactment of the National Security Law, the implementation of 'health code' and the one-year delay of Legislative Council elections (supposed to take place that day). Some were also concerned with the 12 Hong Kong stowaways (some anti-ELAB activists) who were detained in Shenzhen after being caught on a boat to Taiwan in mainland Chinese waters. 289 people were arrested in total that day for participating in demonstrations. [size=no report]

On 7 September 2020, several people staged a 'Lunch with You' demonstration at shopping mall The Landmark in Central district (Hong Kong) against the high number of police arrests during the demonstrations in Mongkok and Yau Ma Tei the day before. Some were seen raising the hand gesture for five demands and singing an anti-ELAB song. Two demonstrators were taken away, one of whom allegedly assaulted a security guard at the mall. [size=several]

On 20 October 2020, villagers bearing long knives, wooden batons and stones assaulted public security officers and criminal investigation bureau officers who conducted unannounced forced eviction and demolition operations in Hantang village, Futang township of Lianshan County (Qingyuan, Guangdong). Thirteen suspects were arrested by the time of reporting on 1 Nov 2020. [size=no report]

On 9 November 2020, hundreds of tenants, suppliers, administrative workers, maintenance staff gathered at the headquarters of a bankrupted residential property management company in Beijing municipality to defend their rights and demand for wage arrears and debt arrears. Physical altercations among participants was reported, though it was not reported whom they clashed with. [size=hundreds]

On 17 November 2020, over 100 residents demonstrated in a residential complex of Xiaotangshan town in Changping district (Beijing) against the town government-backed, black-clad personnel (wearing uniforms typical of riot police) who arrived the night before to enforce a forced eviction operation. They called for their evictors and law enforcement to abide by legal procedures. They chanted slogans, and set up metal barricades to block the entrance of the complex. Clashes were reported between the residents and over 100 armed riot police and security guards present. [size=over 100]

On 19 November 2020, around 100 students, graduates and citizens marched during their graduation ceremony to the University Mall on Chinese University of Hong Kong campus, Shatin district (Hong Kong) (coded as Hong Kong-Sha Tin) to call for the five demands and support for the anti-ELAB movement. Some also held up black balloons, pro-independence slogans and flags. They shouted for the subversion of state power, for freedom and democracy, and the release of the 12 anti-ELAB demonstrators who were arrested in mainland waters while illegally fleeing to Taiwan. Security guards filmed and warned against the demonstration, asking for crowds to disperse. Demonstrators sprayed graffiti on walls, floors and passageways. It was reported that school properties were damaged. [size=around 100]

On 11 January 2021, 8-9 black-clad individuals and students dismantled security fences and chairs outside the University MTR station near the Chinese University of Hong Kong campus at Ma Liu Shui, Shatin district (Hong Kong) (coded as Hong Kong-Sha Tin), and threw white powder at university-hired security guards. The group then shouted slogans against CUHK's closed-campus policy, dissuading students from showing their ID passes before entering campus. One guard was hospitalised due to irritation from the powder, and a university student suspect was arrested on campus later in the afternoon. [size=8-9]

On 21 February 2021, 11 rights defenders were visiting a rights defender - living under residential surveillance in a temporary unit in Sanxi village of Caijiagang residential district (Beibei, Chongqing) - due to Chinese New Year festivities, when they were followed by two unidentified personnel arranged by the government to guard the place. Bodily clashes between the two parties ensued when they tried to take a group photo before leaving the place. [size=at least 11]

On 14 March 2021, a group of middle-aged women and men crowded around a black-clad individual and beat him up as he was leaving a pro-establishment street counter outside SOGO Department Store in Causeway Bay, Wanchai district (Hong Kong) (coded as Hong Kong - Wan Chai). The man had just written foul language on a board belonging to the pro-establishment group. Several LSD members intervened to try to help the man and got into scuffles with the other group. Three people were injured, including the black-clad individual (later hospitalised for injuries tio his hand) and an LSD member (broke her glasses and was bruised). Both of them were arrested at the scene for vandalism and battery respectively. [size=no report]

On 17 March 2021, early in the evening, around 20 shareholders demonstrated ahead of the shareholders' general meeting of a financial services company at Trust Tower in Wan Chai district (Hong Kong) (coded as Hong Kong - Wan Chai). They held up banners to express their complaints. Police officers filmed the demonstration, but did not intervene. It was then reported that around 18 people barged into the shareholders meeting, where the appointment of new board members was scheduled to take place. They vandalised the venue, and scuffled with company employees and security staff. Several company staff was injured. Around 10 rioters were arrested. [size=around 18-20]

On 23 March 2021, in the early morning, a disabled elderly resident was kicked by demolition workers from the Qinzhou District Housing Expropriation Bureau (Tianshui, Gansu). The victim had talked back when the workers arrived with an excavator to demolish the building while residents were still inside, asking that they start with another unit. He was hospitalised and diagnosed with multiple injuries, head hematoma and concussion. [size=no report]

SOURCE: HKFP; Radio Free Asia; AFP; HK01
NOTES: On 12 April 2021, in the early hours, four masked men trespassed on a printing plant in Tsuen Wan district (Hong Kong) (coded as Hong Kong - Tsuen Wan) belonging to Epoch Times, a newspaper and media company affiliated with Falun Gong, a spiritual and religious movement banned in mainland China. They smashed printing equipment and several computer screens with their sledgehammers, and scattered concrete powder and rubble into the core mechanical components. They threatened the staff members on duty, and looted several central processing units (CPUs). [size=4]

On 23 April 2021, 101-1000 taxi drivers demonstrated in Enshi county (Enzhi, Hubei) (coded to Enshi City) when an insurance company refused to renew their insurance policies while citing 'unpaid management fees'. Clashes ensued between the taxi drivers and company staff. [size=101-1000]

SOURCE: Radio Free Asia; AFP; China Aid
NOTES: On 6 June 2021, 3000-4000 students demonstrated at the Nanjing Normal University Zhongbei College in Danyang county (Zhenjiang, Jiangsu) against a Ministry of Education directive to absorb several privately funded independent colleges into vocational schools, for fear that the merger would involve the degrading of their degree qualifications. Students captured the college principal for 30 hours, and tried to prevent police from getting close to him. Bodily clashes ensued between the students, 400 auxiliary and special police officers, and security guards. Students were beaten up, targeted with pepper spray, and carried away. At least 13 independent colleges in Zhejiang and Jiangsu provinces were specified in the directive. [size=3000-4000]

Around 8 June 2021 (as reported), students and parents demonstrated at the Imperial Nanjing University of Chinese Medicine Hanlin College in Taizhou city, Jiangsu province against a Ministry of Education directive to absorb several privately funded independent colleges into vocational schools, for fear that the merger would involve the degrading of their degree qualifications. Teachers intervened and tried to block students from demonstrating. Injuries were reported, although it was not clear who was responsible. At least 13 independent colleges in Zhejiang and Jiangsu provinces were specified in the directive. [size=no report]

On 26 June 2021, dozens of victims' parents clashed with the police during a demonstration march to the Zhecheng County People's Government (Shangqiu, Henan), calling for an investigation into a severe fire accident at a martial arts training centre that caused 18 deaths and 16 injuries involving child athletes. [size=dozens]

On 14 July 2021, from the evening until midnight, over 10,000 residents held a demonstration in Hengda Jinbi Tianxia neighborhood in Jiangjin District, Chongqing over a parking charge dispute. Over 1,000 private security and police forces were deployed at the scene. Police made arrests and were seen beating up residents as they carried arrested residents onto the police vehicle. The police and a demonstrator hit each other inside a police vehicle, while a female demonstrator claimed security officers broke her arm. Some people were arrested. [size=over 10,000]

On 13 September 2021, hundreds of investors demonstrated outside the Shenzhen Evergrande headquarters in Shenzhen to demand repayment of loans and financial products, as the company struggled to repay debts of more than the U.S.$300 billion amid a liquidity crisis. The demonstration escalated to violence as the demonstrators clashed with the police before being dispersed eventually. No arrest was reported. [size=hundreds]

On 21 October 2021, some workers carried banners and blocked entry to a construction site in Mudan district (Heze, Shandong) to demonstrate against wage arrears. While the workers were preventing a car driven by the site supervisor from leaving the site, a worker was run over by the car and suffered from bone fractures and multiple visceral injuries. It immediately triggered a fight between the workers and the driver, causing two people to be hospitalized. [size=some]

On 10 November 2021, a light brawl erupted between Tibetan villagers and local officials at a construction site in Domda village of Yushu City (Yushu, Qinghai) over the failure of authorities to compensate the villagers for land taken from them earlier this year for a construction project. [size=no report]

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: NPP: New Power Party; Government of Taiwan (2016-)
NOTES: On 5 January 2018, dozens of NPP activists and legislators clashed with Taipei police outside the Presidential Office Building while demonstrating against amendments to the Labour Standards Act. Taipei police fenced in the demonstrators and prevented entry to the area. Earlier in the day, 5 NPP legislators broke the doors of the Legislative Yuan and barricaded them with chains, also in demonstration against the Labour Standards Act. [size=dozens]

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: NPP: New Power Party; Government of Taiwan (2016-)
NOTES: On 6 January 2018, tens of NPP activists and legislators demonstrating the draft amendment of the Labour Standards Act clashed with Taipei police just outside the Presidential Office Building after police would not let all of them through without a permit. Police continued to monitor the demonstration throughout the day. [size=tens]

On 8 January 2018, about 300 demonstrators from various labour groups sporadically clashed with Taipei police outside the Legislative Yuan throughout the day during demonstrations against the passage of the Labour Standards Act [size=about 300].

On 9 January 2018, about 170 demonstrators from various labour groups clashed with Taipei police throughout the day outside the Legislative Yuan. More than ten demonstrators also gathered outside the Presidential Office Building and threw shoes. The labour groups were demonstrating against the Labour Standards Act. Also on January 9, 15 labour group demonstrators were arrested by Taipei police for disrupting railway traffic at Taipei Station by lying down on the tracks to demonstrate against the Labour Standards Act. [size=about 185].

On 10 January 2018, Taipei police intervened after Labour group demonstrators threw joss paper and smoke bombs outside the Legislative Yuan. The Labour groups were demonstrating against the Labour Standards Act [size=no report].

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Former Military Forces of Taiwan (2016-); Military Forces of Taiwan (2016-); Police Forces of Taiwan (2016-)
NOTES: On 13 January 2018, police officers in training along with active and retired military personnel gathered outside Zhongxing Hall (Nantou) where the President of Taiwan was visiting to denounce the President for abusing power and undermining military and public officials. Demonstrators briefly clashed with police. [size=no report]

On 20 January 2018, about 30 labour union members and 40 non-union members clashed outside the Meili golf course (New Taipei City-Linkou). The union members were striking to demonstrate against the lay-off of 18 employees while the non-union members countered the demonstration. The company also dispatched 30 private security forces to attempt to break up the strike line twice, but were stopped by local police. [size= about 100]

On 24 January 2018, about 30 members of a self-help group and a student group gathered in the Daguan Community (New Taipei City- Banqiao) to demonstrate against demolition operations set to take place that day. Demonstrators and police clashed twice throughout the day, and one demonstrator threw a smoke bomb. 7 were detained by police. [size=about 30]

On 29 January 2018, unidentified assailants pelted a lawyer's house in Hengchun with asphalt after he attended a demonstration against the development of a new recreation area in Kenting earlier in the day at the Presidential Office Building. [size=no report]

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Former Military Forces of Taiwan (2016-); Former Government of Taiwan (2016-); BSAA: Blue Sky Action Alliance
NOTES: On 27 February 2018, hundreds of military veterans demonstrated outside the Legislative Yuan (Taipei City-Zhongzheng) against government plans to cutback military pensions, engaging in several clashes with the police. Dozens of demonstrators attempted to storm the gates. The leader of the Blue Sky Action Alliance fell and critically injured himself while attempting to scale building; he passed away the following Monday due to his injuries. About 300 of the demonstrators later moved to another street nearby and clashed with independence activists who had a DPP flag displayed in their tent, requiring police intervention to de-escalate the scene. The former Premier of the ROC also attended the demonstration, claiming that he was there to defend the constitution. [size=hundreds]
On 28 February 2018, a group of 10 men, members of the Free Taiwan Party, splashed red paint on the tomb of Chiang Kai Shek in Cihu Mausoleum, Daxi, Taoyuan. [size=10]

On 6 March 2018, about 10 KMT Youth Front members vandalized a pro-independence referendum booth outside the Legislative Yuan (Taipei City-Zhongzheng), beating and smearing the tent set-up with red paint. Police caught 4 suspects. [size=about 10]

On 9 March 2018, 3 demonstrators barged into a press conference in Taipei and sprayed an unidentified substance at the Free Taiwan Party Chairman, in retaliation of the vandalization of Chiang Kai-shek's tomb on 28 February. The demonstrators were later arrested for trespassing. [size=3]

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: CUPP: Chinese Unity Promotion Party; BSAA: Blue Sky Action Alliance
SOURCE: CNA; The News Lens; ET Today; Liberty Times
NOTES: On 22 March 2018, over 100 Blue Sky Action Alliance and CUPP: Chinese Unity Promotion Party garthered in Zhongzheng, Taipei, in memory of a deceased veteran who passed away in an accident during an anti-pension-reform demonstration. More than 70 veteran groups attended the event. One CUPP member displayed five-star flag and other demonstrator(s) who were members of groups opposing pension reforms for veterans argued and clashed physically with the CUPP member because they thought that was inappropriate. A person riding a motorcycle incidentally broke into the demonstration (march) and the some demonstrators thought he did that intentionally. Some people therefore tried attack this individual. The police tried to intervene and make sure the clash did not escalate. [size=over 100]

SOURCE: China Times; New Talk; Liberty Times; ET Today
NOTES: On 24 March 2018, 6 students vandalised the gates and walls of the Executive Yuan and the National Police Agency in Zhongzheng, Taipei because they were dissatisfied that the police who had hurt demonstrators during the Sunflower Movement were not found yet. [size=6]

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Former Police Forces of Taiwan (2016-); Labour Group (Taiwan)
NOTES: On 23 April 2018, retired policemen and firefighters marched from Legislative to Executive Yuan in Taipei, Zhongzheng against pension reform. Clashes between demonstrators and police were reported, no one was injured. [size=no report]

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Former Police Forces of Taiwan (2016-); Labour Group (Taiwan)
NOTES: On 24 April 2018, retired policemen and firefighters marched from Legislative to Executive Yuan in Taipei, Zhongzheng against pension reform. Clashes between demonstrators and police were reported, no one was injured. [size=no report]

SOURCE: AFP; Liberty Times; FTV; The News Lens
NOTES: On 25 April 2018, 800 Heros group demonstrated in Zhongzheng (Taipei) against pension reform. Police intervened after demonstrators tried to break into the Legislative Yuan, leading to a fight. 63 people were arrested, 43 people were injured. [size=no report]

On 27 June 2018, members of LRRA: Labour Rights Referendum Alliance clashed with the police in front of the Ministry of Labour (Taipei City-Zhongzheng) during a demonstration. The LRRA members were angry with the press release issued by the Ministry last week, which they believed tried to threaten workers. One woman was badly injured, but no fatalities were reported. [size=no report]

On 25 July 2018, two groups of political parties and their supporters clashed with each other over the construction plan of the Changhua Railway in Chuanghua City. The police intervened and dispersed the two groups. No death or injuries were reported. [size=no report]

On 4 August 2018, members of Self-Relief Society of Daguan clashed with police in New Taipei City-Banqiao during a demonstration against forced eviction in Daguan. The police dispersed the demonstrators and no injury or death were reported. [size=no report]

On 7 September 2018, almost a hundred investors clashed with the police during a demonstration in front of the Taiwan Futures Exchange in Zhongzheng district of Taipei City. The demonstrators demanded the Futures Exchange to crack down on illegal money laundering and investigate misconduct of the Futures Exchange and futures dealers. [size=almost a hundred]

On 14 September 2018, demonstrators scuffled with the police when they tried to enter the Taichung City Government in Xitun District of Taichung City. The people demonstrated against a court order of demolishment of a local kindergarten. 1 person injured. [size=no report]

On 19 October 2018, over 80 investors staged a demonstration against the Financial Supervisory Commission and clashed with the police outside the Securities and Futures Bureau in Da'an district (Taipei City). The demonstrators tried to enter the building with force but were blocked by the police. [size=over 80]

On 29 October 2018, members of TRU: Taiwan Railway Union demonstrated in front of the Transportation Ministry in Zhongzheng District (Taipei City) after the deadly Puyuma crash. The group tried to enter the building and clashed with the police. They raised six demands, including the right to participate in an ongoing government investigation on the TRA. [size=no report]

On 25 November 2018, three men vandalized the office of a Taipei neighbourhood ward chief with clubs, damaging the door and breaking windows. Police officers suggested that the act was linked with his recent election success. [size=3]

On 1 January 2019, 20-30 members of the Tax and Legal Reform League demonstrated in front of the Presidential Office Building in Zhongzheng, Taipei. Some of the demonstrators were carried away from the scene by the police. The police and the demonstrators were pushing each other and engaged in physical altercation. [size=20-30]

On 13 January 2019, a mob in the hundreds gathered in front of a home in New Taipei City's Luzhou District after a video surfaced on social media of a man assaulting his family. Seven vigilantes stormed the man's home for revenge and police later subdued the situation. [size=hundreds]

On 31 January 2019, the principal of Taichung Liming Kindergarten led demonstrators to the Presidential Office in Zhongzheng, Taipei to demonstrate against the court-ordered demolition of their school. At one point, the principal stuck a pencil into his hand and bled. He refused but was forced to be sent to hospital. The demonstrators tried to enter the presidential office and got into physical altercation with the police trying to block them. One demonstrator who tried to break into the presidential office was arrested. [size=no report]

On 22 February 2019, about 10 college students vandalized the Chiang Kai-shek statue on the National Chengchi University campus in response to a vandalism on the 228 Peace Memorial committed by a pro-China group. [size=about 10]

On 11 March 2019, dozens of members of the Daguan communal group vandalized the Veterans Affairs Council demanding squatter's rights after a court-ordered eviction from the land they lived on, which is owned by council. Police clashed with the demonstrators and arrested several people. [size=dozens]

On 3 April 2019, dozens of fishermen tried to demonstrate outside of the venue in Keelung City of a discussion between the government and representatives of fishermen. They were participants of the discussion but got upset and decided to leave and demonstrate. However they were stopped from doing so by the police and got into physical altercation with the police. [size=dozens]

On 8 April 2019, people in the crowd watching the Dajia Matsu Pilgrimage Procession in Changhua hurled bottles at the procession and clashed with police after the Dajia Matsu sedan was passed to the current head of the CUPP: Chinese Unity Promotion Party. 300 officers were present to monitor the procession and used pepper spray to control the conflict. At least 5 people were hospitalized for injuries, including a reporter and 4 police officers. [size=at least 300]
On 29 May 2019, Uber drivers gathered in front of Executive Yuan to demonstrate against the new Uber regulations. Demonstrators threw eggs and clashed with police on the scene. [size=no report]
